block-definition.translations: de:fange _ _ ca:agafa _ _ es:atrapar _ _ fr:attrape _ _ pt:captura _ _
de:wirf _ ca:llança _ es:lanzar _ fr:lance _ pt:lança _
de:fange _ _ ca:agafa _ _ es:atrapar _ _ fr:attrape _ _ pt:captura _ _
de:wirf _ _ ca:llança _ _ es:lanzar _ _ fr:lance _ _ pt:lança _ _

block-definition.comment: This is a breakpoint block, to be used in debugging. The Boolean input specifies the condition under which the program should pause. (Use True for an unconditional breakpoint.) The intent is that the script should have SHOW VARIABLE blocks for the process's local variables. After the pause, this block automatically hides all temporary variables.
block-definition.translations: de:falls _ dann _ und pause $pause-1-255-220-0 ca:si _ fes _ i atura-ho tot $pause-1-255-220-0 es:si _ haz _ y páralo todo $pause-1-255-220-0 fr:si _ faire _ et mettre tout en pause $pause-1-255-220-0 pt:se _ , então _ e faz pausa em tudo $pause-1-255-220-0

block-definition.comment: This block does nothing. Use it when you are calling a reporter for its side effect and don't care about its return value.
block-definition.translations: de:ignoriere _ ca:ignora _ es:ignorar _ fr:ignore _ pt:ignora _

block-definition.comment: Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) n times where the three input slots are n, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f to represent how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado de _ invocações em cascata de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada _ vegades _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) until condition is true, where the three input slots are condition, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f or condition to indicate how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado da invocação em cascata até que _ de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada fins _ _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Returns the function x↦f(g(x)) where f and g are the two inputs.
block-definition.translations: pt:a composição de _ com _ ca:composa _ _

block-definition.comment: Like the built-in REPEAT UNTIL block, except that the ending condition is not tested until the script has been run the first time. So the script is run at least once.
block-definition.translations: pt:repete _ até que _ $loop-0.7 ca:repeteix _ fins _

block-definition.comment: Run the script repeatedly, as long as the given condition is true. Runs the script at least once before testing the condition.
block-definition.translations: pt:repete _ enquanto _ $loop-0.7 ca:repeteix _ mentre _

block-definition.comment: Runs the script repeatedly, as long as the condition is true. Tests the condition before the first time the script is run. Like the built in REPEAT UNTIL except that in this block the condition must be true, not false.
block-definition.translations: pt:enquanto _ , repete _ $loop-0.7

block-definition.comment: Runs the script the specified number of times, like the built-in REPEAT block, but this one provides the # variable that can be used inside the script. Try REPEAT (200) MOVE (#) STEPS RIGHT 92 with the pen down.
block-definition.translations: pt:repete _ vezes _ _ $loop-0.7 ca:repeteix _ _ _

block-definition.comment: The primitive FOR block uses an implicit step of ±1 depending on which of the starting and ending values is larger. This version allows you to provide an explicit step value. If the sign of the step input is incompatible with the ordering of the starting and ending values, the script will not be run at all.
block-definition.translations: pt:para _ de _ com passo _ a _ _ $loop-0.7 ca:per _ = _ incrementant _ fins _ _

block-definition.comment: Provides LOOP as a function of one input that runs the body of the LET with A set to the function input, so the body can run itself recursively. See COPY block in Variables for an example of use.
block-definition.translations: pt:tendo _ o valor inicial _ , executa _ definido como _ ca:fes que _ sigui _ al _ _

block-definition.comment: Catch errors. Runs the first script. If it succeeds, nothing else happens. But if it has an error (something that would otherwise result in a red halo around the block), then the second script is run, with the text of the error message that would have been shown in the variable ERROR.
block-definition.translations: pt:tenta executar _ e, em caso de erro _ , executa _ ca:prova de forma segura _ i si _ _

block-definition.comment: Throw an error. Makes a red halo appear around the script that runs it, with the input text shown in a speech balloon next to the script, just like any Snap! error. This is useful to put in the second script of SAFELY TRY after some other instructions to undo the partial work of the first script.
block-definition.translations: pt:lança o erro _

block-definition.s: safely try reporting %'this' then if %'error' report %'that'
block-definition.comment: Catch errors in a reporter. Evaluates its first input. If that expression successfully reports a value, this block reports that value. If the expression causes a Snap! error, then the final input slot is evaluated with the text of what would have been the error message in variable ERROR. SAFELY TRY then reports the value of that final expression. Sometimes you'll want to throw an error in the final expression. You can put an ERROR block inside a CALL block to do that.
block-definition.translations: ca:prova de forma segura reportant _ i si _ reportant _

block-definition.comment: Reports a sorted version of the list in its first input slot, using the comparison function in the second input slot. For a list of numbers, using < as the comparison function will sort from low to high; using > will sort from high to low.
block-definition.translations: ca:ordena _ segons criteri _

block-definition.comment: The second input is an "association list," a list of two-item lists. Each of those smaller lists has a "key" as its first item and a "value" as its second. ASSOC reports the first key-value pair in the association list whose key matches the first input.
block-definition.translations: ca:associació _ _

block-definition.comment: This block carries out the given script for each item of the given list, like the primitive FOR EACH. What's different is that it provides the # variable, which will contain the item number in the list of each item in turn, 1 while processing item 1, and so on.
block-definition.translations: ca:_ per cada _ de _ _

block-definition.comment: Takes a (possibly deep) list as input, and reports a human-readable text form of the list (namely, Lisp notation). Will not work on circular lists.
block-definition.translations: ca:notació textual de _

block-definition.comment: SENTENCE is the main constructor for sentences, represented as lists of words. It takes zero or more inputs, each of which can be either a list or a text string. If a list, the input is assumed to be a list of words. If a text string, it is converted to a list of words using SENTENCE→LIST. Then all the lists of words are appended to form a new list of words. If the inputs are lists of lists rather than lists of words, SENTENCE, like APPEND, does only one level of flattening, reporting a list of all the items of all the input lists.
block-definition.translations: ca:frase _

block-definition.comment: ZIP takes any number of lists as inputs. The lists should all be the same length. ZIP reports a list of lists in which the first item is a list of all the first items, the second item is a list of all the second items, etc. Viewing the inputs as the rows of a matrix, ZIP reports its transpose.

Takes as input a function of N inputs and N lists. The function is called with item 1 of all the lists as its inputs, with item 2 of all the lists as its inputs, and so on. (The lists should all be the same length.)
block-definition.translations: ca:multi-mapeja _ sobre _

block-definition.comment: Takes a sentence in text string form and reports the sentence as a list of its words.
block-definition.translations: de:Satz $arrowRight Liste _ ca:frase $arrowRight llista _ es:frase $arrowRight lista _ fr:phrase $arrowRight liste _ pt:uma lista com as palavras da frase _

block-definition.comment: call with True to turn on the entire Scheme numeric tower, including infinite-precision integers, exact rationals, and complex numbers; call with False to restore native JavaScript arithmetic.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera utilização de aritmética do Scheme para _ ca:sistema numèric d'Scheme _

block-definition.comment: The factorial function, to make very large numbers, to demo bignums.
The identity function: reports its input. It's useful to get things like 3/4 or 5-2i into numeric input slots.
Provides Scheme arithmetic functions not in JavaScript
block-definition.translations: pt:_ de _ ca:Scheme _ de _

input.options: number? complex? real? rational? integer? exact? inexact? exact inexact finite? infinite? nan? numerator denominator real-part imag-part magnitude angle

block-definition.translations: pt:o texto multilinha _ ca:multilínia _

block-definition.comment: Reports the part of the first string up to the first instance of the second string inside it. If the second string isn't found, reports the entire first string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:part del text _ anterior a _

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input string starting after the first occurrence of the second string. If the second string isn't found in the first string, reports an empty string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ depois de _ ca:part del text _ posterior a _

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.comment: Reports the character position (starting from 1) of the beginning of the first input string inside the second input string. If it's not found, reports 0.
block-definition.translations: pt:a posição de _ em _ ca:posició de _ en _

block-definition.s: substring of %'str' from position %'start' to position %'end' inclusive
block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input (string) starting at the position given by the second input (counting from 1, like LETTER n OF) and ending at the position given by the third input (also counting from 1). If the third input is empty, reports the portion from the first position to the end of the string. If a position number is negative, counts from the end backward, so -1 is the last character, -2 is the next to last, etc.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ entre as posições _ e _ , inclusive ca:part del text _ des de la posició _ fins _

block-definition.comment: Reports True if the first input string contains the second input string, otherwise false. Comparison is case-independent by default; use USE CASE-INDEPENDENT COMPARISONS to change that.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:text _ conté _ ?

block-definition.s: bitwise unsigned right shift %'a' by %'b' bits
take %'n' items of %'list' starting at %'start' moving %'direction'

block-definition.comment: The stream version of IN FRONT OF. Streams, also called lazy lists, are like lists except that items are not computed until they're needed. This allows for more efficient handling of large computed lists, and even infinite lists. The only piece of magic is here in IN FRONT OF STREAM, whose second input is of type Unevaluated, which means that it's a procedure, with a sort of invisible gray ring. So HEAD OF STREAM is just ITEM 1 OF, but TAIL OF STREAM has a CALL block to make the computation happen. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:a prefixação de _ ao canal _

block-definition.comment: The stream version of variadic MAP (any number of input lists, like MULTIMAP in the list utilities library). Streams, also called lazy lists, are like lists except that items are not computed until they're needed. This allows for more efficient handling of large computed lists, and even infinite lists. The only piece of magic is in IN FRONT OF STREAM, whose second input is of type Unevaluated, which means that it's a procedure, with a sort of invisible gray ring. So HEAD OF STREAM is just ITEM 1 OF, but TAIL OF STREAM has a CALL block to make the computation happen. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:a aplicação de _ aos itens dos canais _

block-definition.s: keep items such that %'pred' from stream %'stream'
block-definition.comment: The stream version of KEEP. Streams, also called lazy lists, are like lists except that items are not computed until they're needed. This allows for more efficient handling of large computed lists, and even infinite lists. The only piece of magic is in IN FRONT OF STREAM, whose second input is of type Unevaluated, which means that it's a procedure, with a sort of invisible gray ring. So HEAD OF STREAM is just ITEM 1 OF, but TAIL OF STREAM has a CALL block to make the computation happen. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:os itens tais que _ do canal _

custom-block.s: keep items such that %predRing from stream %l
keep items such that %predRing from stream %l

block-definition.comment: The inputs are a stream and a positive integer. SHOW STREAM reports a regular finite list of length less than (for short finite streams) or equal to the second input. It's useful because an infinite stream can't be displayed in a finite amount of time.
block-definition.translations: pt:uma lista com os itens do canal _ até ao _ º

block-definition.comment: Make a stream from a finite collection of items, like the LIST primitive. Since this block is typically used for small amounts of data, it does not delay computation of its inputs.
block-definition.translations: pt:um canal com _

block-definition.comment: Call this block with STREAM WITH NUMBERS FROM 2 as its input to get the infinite stream of all the prime numbers. It's called SIEVE because the algorithm it uses is the Sieve of Eratosthenes (clickable link): https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sieve_of_Eratosthenes Look inside; it's a beautifully elegant algorithm. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:a crivagem do canal _

custom-block.s: keep items such that %predRing from stream %l

block-definition.comment: The stream version of NUMBERS FROM 1 TO, with no ending number because it reports the infinite stream of all the integers greater than or equal to its input. Read the code! It's deceptively simple. Streams, also called lazy lists, are like lists except that items are not computed until they're needed. This allows for more efficient handling of large computed lists, and even infinite lists. The only piece of magic is in IN FRONT OF STREAM, whose second input is of type Unevaluated, which means that it's a procedure, with a sort of invisible gray ring. So HEAD OF STREAM is just ITEM 1 OF, but TAIL OF STREAM has a CALL block to make the computation happen. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:um canal com os números a partir de _

block-definition.comment: Read the code while running it,

The inputs are a stream and a positive integer. SHOW STREAM reports a regular finite list of length less than (for short finite streams) or equal to the second input. It's useful because an infinite stream can't be displayed in a finite amount of time.

The stream version of ITEM 1 OF. Streams, also called lazy lists, are like lists except that items are not computed until they're needed. This allows for more efficient handling of large computed lists, and even infinite lists. The only piece of magic is in IN FRONT OF STREAM, whose second input is of type Unevaluated, which means that it's a procedure, with a sort of invisible gray ring. So HEAD OF STREAM is just ITEM 1 OF, but TAIL OF STREAM has a CALL block to make the computation happen. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:o primeiro item do canal _

block-definition.comment: The stream version of ALL BUT FIRST OF. Streams, also called lazy lists, are like lists except that items are not computed until they're needed. This allows for more efficient handling of large computed lists, and even infinite lists. The only piece of magic is in IN FRONT OF STREAM, whose second input is of type Unevaluated, which means that it's a procedure, with a sort of invisible gray ring. So HEAD OF STREAM is just ITEM 1 OF, but TAIL OF STREAM has a CALL block to make the computation happen. For a tutorial introduction to streams, read SICP 3.5: https://mitpress.mit.edu/sites/default/files/sicp/full-text/book/book-Z-H-24.html#%_sec_3.5 or Brian's lecture notes (start on page 74): https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~bh/61a-pages/Volume2/notes.pdf The above are clickable links!
block-definition.translations: pt:um canal com todos os itens de _ menos o primeiro

inputs.input: match allcase-insensitive match all dotall use unicode multi-line

block-definition.comment: Creates a new Regular Expression

input.options: case-insensitive match all multi-line . accepts newlines use unicode

block.l: let flagchain = ""; for (flag of flags.contents) { switch (flag) { case "case-insensitive": flagchain += "i"; break; case "match all": flagchain += "g"; break; case "dotall": flagchain += "s"; break; case "use unicode": flagchain += "u"; break; case "multi-line": flagchain += "m"; break; } } return new RegExp(exp, flagchain);

block-definition.comment: Matches the occurrence of a pattern in a string
Matches the occurrence of a pattern in a string This time, all groups are accounted for in global matches

block.l: let arr = Array.from(str.matchAll(pat)); for (i in arr) { arr[i] = new List(arr[i]); } return new List(arr);

block-definition.comment: Searches for where a pattern occurs in a string
Replace one or more occurrences of a pattern in a string
Joins a list of items by a delimiter

block.l: dict = new Map(dict.entries()) var kvs=[]; for (let i = 0; i < items.contents.length; i++) { kv = items.contents[i].contents dict.set(kv[0],kv[1]); } return dict;
var kvs=[]; for (let i = 0; i < items.contents.length; i++) { kv = items.contents[i].contents kvs.push(kv); } return new Map(kvs);
return new List(Array.from(dict.entries(), x => new List(x)));
var kvs=[]; for (let i = 0; i < items.contents.length; i++) { kv = items.contents[i].contents dict.set(kv[0],kv[1]); }
